utterances.sentences: Well, Virginia is in a pretzel. I don't think it's anything that the Democrats did per se. utterances.speaker: ROB SMITH, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR

utterances.speaker: OSEFO

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let me just ask you, would you forgive any of these Democrats for being in blackface, or is it something they can't recover from, they have to resign immediately?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO

utterances.speaker: SMITH

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, well, this is a learning experience on "Watters' World" as it always is. Let me ask you, Wendy, about some of these comedians and entertainers. Does it make a difference if it's a celebrity in an entertainment capacity to do blackface? Because I don't think it should make a difference.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.sentences: It doesn't make a difference. And to go back to Rob's point. We do not know as a country that blackface is bad, because if we did, people would not do it. People only admit blackface is bad once they get caught. That is an issue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think 99% of the country thinks it is bad.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.sentences: I do not think so because, honestly, what you always hear from people is they say, "I was not trying to make offense to anyone. I was trying to represent a culture. That's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So but if Wendy thinks that the Governor and the AG should resign for being in blackface, what do you think should happen to the celebrities? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: OSEFO

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So I was watching Jimmy Kimmel do Karl Malone, and for me, the most of offensive part of it wasn't him being in blackface, it was like the black voice that he used in that affectation, and you find so much with the liberal comedians that they are given a pass. Ted Danson, Jimmy Kimmel -- all of these people are given a pass. Sarah Silverman has done blackface as well. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: OSEFO

utterances.speaker: SMITH

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: For an Academy Award.

utterances.sentences: "Tropic Thunder." if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: "Tropic Thunder," right. Juan Williams was on "The Five" the other day and he made a differentiation when celebrities do it because he said that when these celebrities and entertainers were doing it, they liked the people that they were imitating in blackface. They were fans of Karl Malone. They were fans of Chris Rock. So he got into the intent. Do you make a differentiation?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.sentences: It's not about the intent because everyone knows the history of blackface - where it comes from - the 1830s, making fun of African- Americans and stereotypes that have been juxtaposed to African-Americans as being lazy and of being ignorant. Those things, you cannot take that away. Blackface represents that. It does not matter what the intent is. It is wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I can't believe people don't know that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And I definitely - yes, and I agree with you on that. I think that people just don't know. There are so many people that I talk to --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I think that people don't know the history behind blackface and why -- and how it has been used to dehumanize African-Americans.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And how these things come up again, again and again. And I think that whenever this happens, we never really go into that conversation, so people can understand why it is so hurtful to African-Americans and to black people, and I think that missed that moment and I don't want to miss that moment this time because I think that this is a teachable lesson.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, coming up. Chris Christie makes his first splash into "Watters' World." And later, "Who's Right and Who's Wrong." "Watters' World" is debuting new segment. Don't miss it.

utterances.speaker: TODD PIRO, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Live from "America's News Headquarters," I'm Todd Piro. A major storm batters Washington State with snow. At least 8 inches filled north of Seattle on Friday. Much of that state covered, causing its Governor to declare a state of emergency. Authorities are urging residents to stay off the roads due to dangerous conditions. Snow also prompted a rescue effort in California. Crews there had to travel by snowmobile after 7 feet of snow left 120 people trapped at a resort in Sierra Nevada for five days. Forecasters say a storm like this one hasn't been seen in many years. And Prince Philip has given up driving for good. In a statement, Buckingham Palace says the 97-year-old has decided to voluntarily surrender his license. The decision comes less than a month after the Prince was involved in an accident which left two women injured. I'm Todd Piro. Now back to "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CHRISTIE, R-N.J., FORMER GOVERNOR
utterances.sentences: Sit down and shut up. Get the hell off the beach. It's 4:30, you've maximized your tan. Get off the beach. Are you stupid? On topic. On topic. Next question. A thousand things I will do tonight. Going to dinner with you is about 1,0001. Your rear-end is going to get thrown jail, idiot. You're a big shot. Either sit down and keep quiet or get out. One or the other. We are done with you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's the Chris Christie that everybody remembers from back in the day, basically just telling people what's going on. In 2016, the Governor ran for President, and now, three years later, he is the author of a new book, "Let me Finish." Detailing his rise in New Jersey politics and his insight into the Trump presidency, Chris Christie joins me now. Governor, I used to get drunk with my friend and watch you on YouTube just laying people out.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: I am glad I was entertaining when you were drunk, that's good. Well, you're my entertainment now. I love your show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you very much. You have a great taste. Now, unlike a lot of the other people that interviewed you, I actually read this thing.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: I know and I am going to be able to tell right away. I can tell the people who didn't read it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I skipped the New Jersey part, I went straight to the 2016 campaign.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, I confess. Now, in the campaign, you really went after Marco Rubio hard.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You -- actually, a very famous moment of the campaign was when you got him so flummoxed, he started repeating himself in the New Hampshire debate. Let's roll that and then talk about it.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MARCO RUBIO, R-FLA.
utterances.sentences: But I would add this. Let's just start with this fiction that Barack Obama doesn't know what he is doing. He knows exactly what he is doing. He is trying to change this country. He wants America to become more like the rest of the world. We don't want to be like the rest of the world. We want to be the United States of America.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: You see, everybody, I want the people at home to think about this. That's what Washington, D.C. does. The drive-by shot at the beginning with incorrect and incomplete information, and then the memorized 25-second speech. That is exactly what divides this nation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And the crowd loved it and then I think he repeated the same line --

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Three more times.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Three more times. Now, do you guys talk after that? You guys are friends?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes. We are fine. Listen, in fact, after Marco had his debate for his Senate seat then that he ran for reelection for, he called me the next day and he said, "By the way, thank you." And I said "Why?" And he said, "I did great in my debate last night and all I was thinking about what you did to me in February and I am never going to let anybody do that to me again."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So you warmed him up.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: We did. And I think that Marco understood. We were competing with each other. We were in direct competition with each other in New Hampshire and I did what I thought I needed to do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you got some big endorsements in New Hampshire and your poll numbers really started to rise and you were really the attack dog for a lot of that primary campaign, and then you dropped out, endorsed Donald Trump. Tell us about the endorsement. You went down to Texas.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes, we want to Fort Worth. I flew down there the night he was having a debate in Houston. I met him in Fort Worth and we did the endorsement, and I remember, we kept it so quiet, no leaks that when we walked into that room that you are showing on the air right now, a reporter saw me walk into the room with Trump and said, "Oh, my god." They were stunned. But here is what I knew. I knew he was going to be the nominee.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because you endorsed him before almost anybody else.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Before anybody.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Before Jeff Sessions.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Before anybody. I endorsed him. He was my friend for 15 years at that point. But also, I had campaigned against him. I knew he was going to be the Republican nominee and my job, as I saw was to endorse him and to go in there and make him the best candidate he could be because we did not want Hillary Clinton to be President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right, then so you're a big part of the campaign at that point, moving on to the fall and the "Access Hollywood" tape drops. What went through your mind when "Access Hollywood" drops?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Listen, I think we were all stunned and worried and concerned. But one of the things I said to the then candidate at the time was, he said, "Is it over?" And I said to him, "No, because you are running against the single worst presidential candidate in my lifetime." So we got time to recover, but we've got to do this the right way. And he went into that debate that Sunday night and he dealt with the issue, and he really, really performed well in that debate and that plus Jim Comey's little letter, I think turned momentum and now, we have Donald Trump as President.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right, now, so there is some controversy about you in that second debate. There are people in the campaign that say, "Chris Christie had the opportunity to fly on the jet with the team and go to that debate in Houston," and you decided that morning maybe not to go, and people thought that was a little disloyal.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes, well, listen, that's Steve Bannon who is just making stuff up telling me, you're either on the plane or you are off the team. Typical Steve drama that was completely made up. I made it really clear, I called that morning and said, "Listen, I'm only elected official here. And you haven't yet answered these questions. And if I go there, they are going to be all over me to answer these questions. I want you to answer them first." The same reason I didn't go on Sunday morning shows that Sunday before the debate. The president knew full well I wasn't going and that night, after the debate was over, 10 minutes after it was over. He called me and he said, "I won the debate because of you. You are the best campaign debate prepper I have ever seen. Will you still run the debate prep for debate number three?" So this whole idea that I was off the team, I was there and then on election tonight, I was in his apartment with he, and Melania and Baron and the rest of the family watching election returns. So, another Steve Bannon fiction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, and that was a great night, that election night.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: It was an amazing night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Amazing historic comeback.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: No one thought it, Jesse, no one thought it was going to happen when the exit polls came in at 5:30 showing Hillary Clinton was going to win 350 electoral votes, believe, me down the street at Trump Tower, there was a lot of consternation. But it made it only better when those returns came in and it went all away and he was one very happy man that night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You were in the running for, I believe, it was Attorney General and maybe another Cabinet position and you were also in charge of the transition. Now, Chris Christie is out writing books. He is not in the White House at all, what happened?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Well, I was in the running for Vice President and it came down to me and Mike Pence and he selected Governor Pence, and I love Governor Pence and I think he was a good choice. I was then in the running for Attorney General, he picked Jeff Sessions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, imagine if Chris Christie had been AG.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: There would be no Bob Mueller if Chris Christie was AG. That you could be sure of, and on the transition stuff, two days after the election, I started writing the book. Steve Bannon called me in and fired me as Chairman of the transition and when - I knew it wasn't his doing, so I said, "Whose decision was this?" I thought, perhaps, it was the President-elect, and I said I wanted to talk to him directly. And he finally said to me, "No," as he referred to him, he said, "It was the kid." Referring to Jared Kushner. And he said, "It's the kid. He's been taking an ax to your head ever since I got here with the boss." Ancient bitterness. And so, you know, this goes back to, as I detail in the book, the time in 2004 when I prosecuted Jared's father.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'd be pretty mad, too.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I am sure you would be at the time, but then 12 years later, Jesse, once you knew that your father had committed those crimes, that your father had pled guilty, not been found guilty, but admitted to the crimes, what else was I supposed to do as a prosecutor? Turn my head and walk away?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I understand.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: I took an oath, and so in the end also, we're supposed to be serving the President and by throwing me out and throwing the entire six months of transition work out, the President is still trying to recover from that with a lot of empty tests and a lot of people got picked for jobs like Mike Flynn and Tom Price and others who had no business being there and served the President poorly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, that would have been a lot of fun having you as AG, telling people to sit down and shut up in the press corps, that would have been --

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Let me tell you something, you know what happened, too, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. All right, Governor, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it. Coming up. Our new segment, "Who's Right and Who's Wrong?" But up next, Diamond and Silk, on O.J. Simpson making some news.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Liz Warren's past coming back to bite her. "The Washington Post" unearthing the Massachusetts Senator's card for the Texas Bar. In '86, she signed it herself listing her race as American Indian. The 2020 hopeful issuing yet another apology for her ancestral claims.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.sentences: I am sorry that I extended confusion about tribal citizenship and tribal sovereignty and for harm caused. I am also sorry for not being more mindful of this decades ago. I am not a member of a tribe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Have you dropping out of the race?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Bye, Warren. See you later. Diamond and Silk join me now. Ladies, this is bad. This is really bad.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.sentences: Yes. It is bad, Jesse. You know, I don't think that she should drop out. She is not going to win, no way. But here is the deal. A little lie turns into a big lie, and then a big lie turns into a well-dressed lie. Just remind Rachel Dolezal, remember that when she walked out and she said she was African American and come to find out she was white.

utterances.speaker: SILK, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: So, I don't know why Elizabeth Warren keeps running away from her race. Maybe she should embrace it. She should take this time to step down and embrace really who she is so that she can stop lying to the public.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, she is white. Look in the mirror. She is pale. She is white. Her name is Elizabeth Fleming Warren. I mean, I had my DNA tested. I'm 0.1% black. She is 0.09% American Indian. I'm more black than she is Indian.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Just like Silk is more Indian than she is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You are?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Look at her high cheeckbones.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's what got Liz Warren in trouble with the cheekbones. Oh, boy. All right, let's go on to O.J. Simpson. You know, he was talking about Roger Stone who complained about the FBI using some brutal tactics in the raid at his house early in the morning. Here is the Juice on Roger Stone.

utterances.speaker: O.J. SIMPSON, FORMER FOOTBALL PLAYER
utterances.sentences: I got raided by the FBI in Miami. During this time, FBI agents, 5:00 in the morning. I had more than dogs. I had kids there. They were traumatizing my friend. He got raided, too. For nothing. Interesting task force. They were wrong. You never heard another word about it after the media made a big deal out of them in there. So the FBI can be wrong, but to try to compare it to El Chapo and bin Laden. Hey, man, bin Laden was carried out in a bag, not walked out in handcuffs. So you know, man up. Stop crying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When O.J. tells you to man up, I say, "Okay, whatever you say, O.J. Whatever you say."

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Yes, maybe O.J. should go and out squeeze himself. You know, telling him to man up, maybe O.J. should have manned up and continued to do the rest of his years in prison instead of out walking around. The deal is, Roger Stone, I thought it was excessive as to what happened to him.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Agents raiding his house, walking up to his house, bum rushing his house to arrest him and then he goes to sign the stuff out. It was ridiculous. A waste of taxpayer's money. Listen, he has already pleaded not guilty. So let this here be, go to a trial and be judged by a jury of his peers.

utterances.speaker: WATTER

utterances.utterance: Well, it's a Democratic problem in Virginia.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: No, it's not. So to speak because we've had other issues in Virginia, Charlottesville, hello that has not been a Democratic problem. So racism --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so we're just talking about the blackface and I get your point.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: So racism is as American as apple pie and that's not something that we can argue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What are you calling them to do?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: I am asking that they step down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All of them?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: I believe that the AG, as well as the Governor should step down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So the two guys in blackface, you want them out.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Should step down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you want the black Lieutenant Governor accused of sexual assault to be Governor?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: No, I want the claims brought against him to be substantiated. We need to see this substantiated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, I agree with that. Rob, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: ROB SMITH, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR
utterances.utterance: I think that it's very funny when you see Democrats being racist, basically, then racism is all of a sudden an American problem.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: It's always been, Rob.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And whenever there is a racial issue on the Republican side, then it's an example of some sort of deep rooted issue with racism in the Republican Party.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Look at the policies you guys put forward.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let me just ask you, would you forgive any of these Democrats for being in blackface, or is it something they can't recover from, they have to resign immediately?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I think for me, you know, look, I don't think that it's something they can't recover from. I don't know if I necessarily want people to resign immediately. We were on here, I was with you when we talked about Roseanne when the whole incident happened with her. And I feel that in situations like this, we always lose the opportunity to have a learning experience. I think that people realize that blackface is bad, but when we have these opportunities to tell them why it's bad, they just don't get it, and we don't teach them that. I think that it's absolutely crazy ...

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: People don't realize blackface is bad.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: ... that these people wearing black face, and by the way, that yearbook was when he was 25 years old. So he was an adult.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, well, this is a learning experience on "Watters' World" as it always is. Let me ask you, Wendy, about some of these comedians and entertainers. Let's take a look at some of their blackface episodes. We had Ted Danson, famously, in black face many, many years ago at an event. There he is right there. I mean, that's pretty outrageous. You had Jimmy Kimmel not too long ago dressed up as Karl Malone. I mean, he's a big Karl Malone fan. I can't believe you can even find this online. Jimmy Fallon, I think was Chris Rock at one point. Does it make a difference if it's a celebrity in an entertainment capacity to do blackface? Because I don't think it should make a difference.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: It doesn't make a difference. And to go back to Rob's point. We do not know as a country that blackface is bad, because if we did, people would not do it. People only admit blackface is bad once they get caught. That is an issue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think 99% of the country thinks it is bad.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: I do not think so because, honestly, what you always hear from people is they say, "I was not trying to make offense to anyone. I was trying to represent a culture. That's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So but if Wendy thinks that the Governor and the AG should resign for being in blackface, what do you think should happen to the celebrities?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: I absolutely think that there should be ramifications for their --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ramifications.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. They can't resign, they are not in the political --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No more late-night shows?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: No more. No, seriously.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: So I was watching Jimmy Kimmel do Karl Malone, and for me, the most of offensive part of it wasn't him being in blackface, it was like the black voice that he used in that affectation, and you find so much with the liberal comedians that they are given a pass. Ted Danson, Jimmy Kimmel -- all of these people are given a pass. Sarah Silverman has done blackface as well.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Yes, she has blackface as well.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And so you never really see that outrage from the public for this - -

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think Robert Downey, Jr., he was in blackface. He was nominated.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: For an Academy Award.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Yes, he sure was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When he was in blackface, what was that movie?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: "Tropic Thunder."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "Tropic Thunder," right. Juan Williams was on "The Five" the other day and he made a differentiation when celebrities do it because he said that when these celebrities and entertainers were doing it, they liked the people that they were imitating in blackface. They were fans of Karl Malone. They were fans of Chris Rock. So he got into the intent. Do you make a differentiation?

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: It's not about the intent because everyone knows the history of blackface - where it comes from - the 1830s, making fun of African- Americans and stereotypes that have been juxtaposed to African-Americans as being lazy and of being ignorant. Those things, you cannot take that away. Blackface represents that. It does not matter what the intent is. It is wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I can't believe people don't know that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And I definitely - yes, and I agree with you on that. I think that people just don't know. There are so many people that I talk to --

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: I think they don't care.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I think that people don't know the history behind blackface and why -- and how it has been used to dehumanize African-Americans.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And how these things come up again, again and again. And I think that whenever this happens, we never really go into that conversation, so people can understand why it is so hurtful to African-Americans and to black people, and I think that missed that moment and I don't want to miss that moment this time because I think that this is a teachable lesson.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, well, Wendy, I think your mom would be proud because you didn't yell at anybody this time.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Hey mom, I don't yell.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Because we can agree that blackface is wrong.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Liberal conservative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, guys, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: OSEFO
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, coming up. Chris Christie makes his first splash into "Watters' World." And later, "Who's Right and Who's Wrong." "Watters' World" is debuting new segment. Don't miss it.

utterances.speaker: TODD PIRO, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Live from "America's News Headquarters," I'm Todd Piro. A major storm batters Washington State with snow. At least 8 inches filled north of Seattle on Friday. Much of that state covered, causing its Governor to declare a state of emergency. Authorities are urging residents to stay off the roads due to dangerous conditions. Snow also prompted a rescue effort in California. Crews there had to travel by snowmobile after 7 feet of snow left 120 people trapped at a resort in Sierra Nevada for five days. Forecasters say a storm like this one hasn't been seen in many years. And Prince Philip has given up driving for good. In a statement, Buckingham Palace says the 97-year-old has decided to voluntarily surrender his license. The decision comes less than a month after the Prince was involved in an accident which left two women injured. I'm Todd Piro. Now back to "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CHRISTIE, R-N.J., FORMER GOVERNOR
utterances.utterance: Sit down and shut up. Get the hell off the beach. It's 4:30, you've maximized your tan. Get off the beach. Are you stupid? On topic. On topic. Next question. A thousand things I will do tonight. Going to dinner with you is about 1,0001. Your rear-end is going to get thrown jail, idiot. You're a big shot. Either sit down and keep quiet or get out. One or the other. We are done with you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's the Chris Christie that everybody remembers from back in the day, basically just telling people what's going on. In 2016, the Governor ran for President, and now, three years later, he is the author of a new book, "Let me Finish." Detailing his rise in New Jersey politics and his insight into the Trump presidency, Chris Christie joins me now. Governor, I used to get drunk with my friend and watch you on YouTube just laying people out.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: I am glad I was entertaining when you were drunk, that's good. Well, you're my entertainment now. I love your show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, thank you very much. You have a great taste. Now, unlike a lot of the other people that interviewed you, I actually read this thing.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: I know and I am going to be able to tell right away. I can tell the people who didn't read it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I skipped the New Jersey part, I went straight to the 2016 campaign.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, I confess. Now, in the campaign, you really went after Marco Rubio hard.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You -- actually, a very famous moment of the campaign was when you got him so flummoxed, he started repeating himself in the New Hampshire debate. Let's roll that and then talk about it.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MARCO RUBIO, R-FLA.
utterances.utterance: But I would add this. Let's just start with this fiction that Barack Obama doesn't know what he is doing. He knows exactly what he is doing. He is trying to change this country. He wants America to become more like the rest of the world. We don't want to be like the rest of the world. We want to be the United States of America.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: You see, everybody, I want the people at home to think about this. That's what Washington, D.C. does. The drive-by shot at the beginning with incorrect and incomplete information, and then the memorized 25-second speech. That is exactly what divides this nation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the crowd loved it and then I think he repeated the same line --

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Three more times.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Three more times. Now, do you guys talk after that? You guys are friends?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Yes. We are fine. Listen, in fact, after Marco had his debate for his Senate seat then that he ran for reelection for, he called me the next day and he said, "By the way, thank you." And I said "Why?" And he said, "I did great in my debate last night and all I was thinking about what you did to me in February and I am never going to let anybody do that to me again."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So you warmed him up.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: We did. And I think that Marco understood. We were competing with each other. We were in direct competition with each other in New Hampshire and I did what I thought I needed to do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you got some big endorsements in New Hampshire and your poll numbers really started to rise and you were really the attack dog for a lot of that primary campaign, and then you dropped out, endorsed Donald Trump. Tell us about the endorsement. You went down to Texas.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Yes, we want to Fort Worth. I flew down there the night he was having a debate in Houston. I met him in Fort Worth and we did the endorsement, and I remember, we kept it so quiet, no leaks that when we walked into that room that you are showing on the air right now, a reporter saw me walk into the room with Trump and said, "Oh, my god." They were stunned. But here is what I knew. I knew he was going to be the nominee.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because you endorsed him before almost anybody else.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Before anybody.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Before Jeff Sessions.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Yes. Before anybody. I endorsed him. He was my friend for 15 years at that point. But also, I had campaigned against him. I knew he was going to be the Republican nominee and my job, as I saw was to endorse him and to go in there and make him the best candidate he could be because we did not want Hillary Clinton to be President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, then so you're a big part of the campaign at that point, moving on to the fall and the "Access Hollywood" tape drops. What went through your mind when "Access Hollywood" drops?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Listen, I think we were all stunned and worried and concerned. But one of the things I said to the then candidate at the time was, he said, "Is it over?" And I said to him, "No, because you are running against the single worst presidential candidate in my lifetime." So we got time to recover, but we've got to do this the right way. And he went into that debate that Sunday night and he dealt with the issue, and he really, really performed well in that debate and that plus Jim Comey's little letter, I think turned momentum and now, we have Donald Trump as President.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right, now, so there is some controversy about you in that second debate. There are people in the campaign that say, "Chris Christie had the opportunity to fly on the jet with the team and go to that debate in Houston," and you decided that morning maybe not to go, and people thought that was a little disloyal.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, listen, that's Steve Bannon who is just making stuff up telling me, you're either on the plane or you are off the team. Typical Steve drama that was completely made up. I made it really clear, I called that morning and said, "Listen, I'm only elected official here. And you haven't yet answered these questions. And if I go there, they are going to be all over me to answer these questions. I want you to answer them first." The same reason I didn't go on Sunday morning shows that Sunday before the debate. The president knew full well I wasn't going and that night, after the debate was over, 10 minutes after it was over. He called me and he said, "I won the debate because of you. You are the best campaign debate prepper I have ever seen. Will you still run the debate prep for debate number three?" So this whole idea that I was off the team, I was there and then on election tonight, I was in his apartment with he, and Melania and Baron and the rest of the family watching election returns. So, another Steve Bannon fiction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, and that was a great night, that election night.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: It was an amazing night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Amazing historic comeback.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: No one thought it, Jesse, no one thought it was going to happen when the exit polls came in at 5:30 showing Hillary Clinton was going to win 350 electoral votes, believe, me down the street at Trump Tower, there was a lot of consternation. But it made it only better when those returns came in and it went all away and he was one very happy man that night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You were in the running for, I believe, it was Attorney General and maybe another Cabinet position and you were also in charge of the transition. Now, Chris Christie is out writing books. He is not in the White House at all, what happened?

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Well, I was in the running for Vice President and it came down to me and Mike Pence and he selected Governor Pence, and I love Governor Pence and I think he was a good choice. I was then in the running for Attorney General, he picked Jeff Sessions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, imagine if Chris Christie had been AG.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: There would be no Bob Mueller if Chris Christie was AG. That you could be sure of, and on the transition stuff, two days after the election, I started writing the book. Steve Bannon called me in and fired me as Chairman of the transition and when - I knew it wasn't his doing, so I said, "Whose decision was this?" I thought, perhaps, it was the President-elect, and I said I wanted to talk to him directly. And he finally said to me, "No," as he referred to him, he said, "It was the kid." Referring to Jared Kushner. And he said, "It's the kid. He's been taking an ax to your head ever since I got here with the boss." Ancient bitterness. And so, you know, this goes back to, as I detail in the book, the time in 2004 when I prosecuted Jared's father.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'd be pretty mad, too.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, I am sure you would be at the time, but then 12 years later, Jesse, once you knew that your father had committed those crimes, that your father had pled guilty, not been found guilty, but admitted to the crimes, what else was I supposed to do as a prosecutor? Turn my head and walk away?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I understand.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: I took an oath, and so in the end also, we're supposed to be serving the President and by throwing me out and throwing the entire six months of transition work out, the President is still trying to recover from that with a lot of empty tests and a lot of people got picked for jobs like Mike Flynn and Tom Price and others who had no business being there and served the President poorly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, that would have been a lot of fun having you as AG, telling people to sit down and shut up in the press corps, that would have been --

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Let me tell you something, you know what happened, too, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. All right, Governor, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIE
utterances.utterance: Thanks for having me on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Appreciate it. Coming up. Our new segment, "Who's Right and Who's Wrong?" But up next, Diamond and Silk, on O.J. Simpson making some news.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Liz Warren's past coming back to bite her. "The Washington Post" unearthing the Massachusetts Senator's card for the Texas Bar. In '86, she signed it herself listing her race as American Indian. The 2020 hopeful issuing yet another apology for her ancestral claims.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.utterance: I am sorry that I extended confusion about tribal citizenship and tribal sovereignty and for harm caused. I am also sorry for not being more mindful of this decades ago. I am not a member of a tribe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Have you dropping out of the race?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bye, Warren. See you later. Diamond and Silk join me now. Ladies, this is bad. This is really bad.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.utterance: Yes. It is bad, Jesse. You know, I don't think that she should drop out. She is not going to win, no way. But here is the deal. A little lie turns into a big lie, and then a big lie turns into a well-dressed lie. Just remind Rachel Dolezal, remember that when she walked out and she said she was African American and come to find out she was white.

utterances.speaker: SILK, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: So, I don't know why Elizabeth Warren keeps running away from her race. Maybe she should embrace it. She should take this time to step down and embrace really who she is so that she can stop lying to the public.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, she is white. Look in the mirror. She is pale. She is white. Her name is Elizabeth Fleming Warren. I mean, I had my DNA tested. I'm 0.1% black. She is 0.09% American Indian. I'm more black than she is Indian.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Just like Silk is more Indian than she is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You are?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Look at her high cheeckbones.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's what got Liz Warren in trouble with the cheekbones. Oh, boy. All right, let's go on to O.J. Simpson. You know, he was talking about Roger Stone who complained about the FBI using some brutal tactics in the raid at his house early in the morning. Here is the Juice on Roger Stone.

utterances.speaker: O.J. SIMPSON, FORMER FOOTBALL PLAYER
utterances.utterance: I got raided by the FBI in Miami. During this time, FBI agents, 5:00 in the morning. I had more than dogs. I had kids there. They were traumatizing my friend. He got raided, too. For nothing. Interesting task force. They were wrong. You never heard another word about it after the media made a big deal out of them in there. So the FBI can be wrong, but to try to compare it to El Chapo and bin Laden. Hey, man, bin Laden was carried out in a bag, not walked out in handcuffs. So you know, man up. Stop crying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When O.J. tells you to man up, I say, "Okay, whatever you say, O.J. Whatever you say."

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Yes, maybe O.J. should go and out squeeze himself. You know, telling him to man up, maybe O.J. should have manned up and continued to do the rest of his years in prison instead of out walking around. The deal is, Roger Stone, I thought it was excessive as to what happened to him.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Agents raiding his house, walking up to his house, bum rushing his house to arrest him and then he goes to sign the stuff out. It was ridiculous. A waste of taxpayer's money. Listen, he has already pleaded not guilty. So let this here be, go to a trial and be judged by a jury of his peers.

utterances.speaker: WATTER
utterances.utterance: All right, now, one of the other controversies this week. Do you guys remember this scene from "Mary Poppins?"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay. So the "New York Times" now claiming Mary Poppins is racist because they had some soot on their faces during the chimney sweep.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Okay, so why do we allow these people to manipulate our language and say it's racist? Or what we say is racist? Our TV shows are racist? Now Disney movies are racist? This is crazy. But I didn't see them mentioning anything about Jimmy Kimmel dressing up in black face, I didn't see them mentioning anything about Joy Behar dressing like a beautiful African-American woman. I just wish that the left would stop attacking everything and making everything racist. Because it's getting out of control. That "Mary Poppins" movie was not racist. So stop it "New York Times" stop it.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right, and understand what racist is. It is whenever a person thinks they are more superior than another group of people. That's what it is. So stop calling everybody racist because the definition of racist is just going away. You are not understanding what the definition is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you remember what the "New York Times" called blackface when the Democrat had it on. They called it dark makeup. So they are always trying to shade something one way. What was Elizabeth Warren's middle name? Herring. I said it was Flemming. I do not want to misidentify Elizabeth Warren.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: No, we got it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, ladies. Catch them on the "Chit-Chat Tour."

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Chitchattour.com.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There is it is. Up next, "Who is Right and Who is Wrong?" Probably me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Last week's Super Bowl, pretty boring, including the halftime show. Although many people are up in arms over Adam Levine's shirtless performance.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Ayesha Tyler tweeted quote, "Why is it okay to see Adam Levine's boobs and not Janet Jackson's? Asking for a friend." So do you think there is a double standard with male and female nudity?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So we thought we'd ask who is right and who is wrong. Joining me now, the newest addition to the Fox Nation family, Abby Hornacek and Fox News 24/7 Headlines reporter, Carley Shimkus. All right, so in my opinion, is it okay for men to take their shirts off in public? When is it okay and when is it not okay?

utterances.speaker: ABBY HORNACEK, HOST, FOX NATION
utterances.utterance: I feel like it really depends on the situation. See, I am kind of proponent of if -- did you see all of the memes and stuff that came out that people released on Twitter, they were like, the beard gut guys that were kind of mimicking Adam Levine. That I think is okay. I think it's hilarious.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, you like fat guys when they take their shirts off? That's okay.

utterances.speaker: CARLEY SHIMKUS, REPORTER
utterances.utterance: There's a lot of guys out there right now and you're their favorite on TV.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I think it's hilarious. I am not a huge fan of gym selfies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, so you are making fun of them.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, you're making fun of fat guys.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I am not making fun of them. They are making fun of themselves.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you agree? Do you think fat guys --

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Do not twist my words.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: I cannot believe that this not only was a question after the Super Bowl halftime show that it actually went viral. And people were outraged talking about there being a double standard with men and women.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, the male nipple is it equivalent to the female nipple?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: That is when you know that things are going well in this country when you are actually outraged by Adam Levine being topless at the Super Bowl halftime show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You liked it, Carley, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: No, you know what? I didn't like the fact that he took his shirt off during the Super Bowl halftime show. I thought it was a little cringe worthy. A lot cringed for it actually.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because of the tattoos.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, the California tattoo above his belly button is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So you guys are anti-tattoos.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I don't have any tattoos, but that would really hurt, right?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Terrible choice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so we're asking the audience ...

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Or tickle, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is it appropriate for men to take their shirts off in public? Not including the beach or jogging, just generally. We're going to ask you guys, and then we'll report next week. Okay, this is the next topic. We are going to get into this right now. When cities win championships such as Boston, New England, they won the championship. There were some brawls going out on the streets. They shouldn't even be fighting because they win every year, but is it okay when cities riot a little bit? When the Eagles --

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: A little bit? Do you remember what happened last year? People were burning couches and flipping cars. That is not okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What if they haven't won a championship in many decades?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: No, I will never understand why people get destructive after a win.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Right, I don't -- that's exactly what I was going to say. I don't understand it. You should be happy, you should be celebrating. You should be climbing up light posts like the Eagles fans. You shouldn't be rioting. You shouldn't be getting mad at each other.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: And they be hugging.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: You know what this is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, no, it's exuberance. They are not trying to destroy property because they are angry. They are destroying property because they are happy.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: In the first -- that doesn't -- in the first segment ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Men like to break things.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: We established that there was a difference between men and women, this is a prime example of it.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Definitely.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Where men go to destruction and crazy town and women just, you know, kind of want to have a little bit of fun.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I'll say this, I was so excited to meet Carley. She is also tall. She is a lot more beautiful than I am, but I was so excited, but I am not going to go beat her up. I am going to be happy and I hug --

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: I feel much more comfortable --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, yes, ladies, please don't fight. We can't have that on "Watters' World." Okay, lastly, you know when you're in a plane. Have you guys ever been on an airplane waiting to take off and someone loses it, someone has to get hogtied off by marshals or someone starts letting loose on one of the fellow passengers.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: We were on the same plane the other day, I think that was you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, that was David Schwimmer. What is your move, in your opinion, if you are a fellow passenger and you see someone go bananas?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: I have never -- this has never happened on a flight of mine, but I've always wanted it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You want to have this sight.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, because then it's a topic of conversation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you take your phone out or do you try to intervene.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Absolutely phone out, not intervening whatsoever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then do you put it on "Fox and Friends" first.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Hundred percent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you do? Do you try to wrestle them away?

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Let me ask you, I mean, was this after the Patriots just won the Super Bowl? Are these Patriots fans?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is not a riot.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Is this a sequel to the first video we watched.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I think she is just angry because she has been waiting on the plane for a long time.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: It's not okay because then you have to sit next to that person and they are obviously getting -- taken off the plane, but I mean, why make a scene? You are not going anywhere. You are literally on the ground

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But if you are next to them, what's the move? Do you sit quietly and try not to get injured? Or do you try to break it up? Break it off?

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I will tell you this, I was on an elevator once in my building and there were two dogs that started fighting and I kind of reached down there, I still have a scar on my hand because the dogs bit me and I am like, if these are people, I think I am never going to try to break people up. I've learned my lesson. I'm going to stay out of it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, so you say stay out of it. You say stay out of it.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Stay out of it or intervene. I am going with -- I will be a hero, I will intervene --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you're going to videotape.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: And I will videotape.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: I will videotape while you intervene.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: I wear many hats in this fight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, "Who is Right and Who is Wrong." We'll let the audience decide. Ladies, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: HORNACEK
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, up next the five things you didn't know about me. Get ready for this, up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Time for "Last Call." People seem to think they know a lot about me since they see me on TV. But I bet you didn't know this. I used to play the flute. You probably didn't think I had any musical talent anyway because you have seen my dance moves in the breaks. But I was really good. Just ask my mom. And if you want to know some more things about me. Head over to Fox News Insider, "The Five Things You Didn't Know About Jesse Watters." That's all for us tonight.
